The Buddha said:
Listen to it, keep it in your mind.
Those elders who can uphold the four precepts without transgression will be respected by people in this life and will be reborn in the heavens in the next life.
First, do not kill any living beings; second, do not steal; third, do not lust after others' spouses; fourth, do not speak falsely or engage in divisive speech.
If your mind desires greed, anger, or delusion, restrain yourself and do not indulge.
Those who cannot control these four intentions will have their bad reputation heard daily, like the waning light of the moon at the end of the month.
Those who can restrain their evil intentions will be like the waxing light of the new moon, gradually brightening until the fifteenth day when it is full.
The Buddha said:
There are also six things that will cause one's wealth to be depleted daily.
First, delighting in drinking alcohol;
second, delighting in gambling;
third, delighting in going to bed early and rising late;
fourth, delighting in inviting guests and also wanting others to invite oneself;
Fifth, they delight in associating with bad friends;
Sixth, they are arrogant and look down on others.

Violating the first four evils and engaging in these six things obstructs their wholesome conduct. They cannot worry about livelihood, and their wealth diminishes day by day. What benefit is there in bowing to the six directions?
The Buddha said:
There are four kinds of bad friends:
First, those who harbor resentment within but outwardly pretend to be friends;
Second, those who speak kindly to people's faces but slander them behind their backs;
Third, those who feign sorrow in front of people but rejoice behind their backs when they are in need;
Fourth, those who outwardly appear close but secretly plot harm.
There are also four kinds of good friends:
First, those who outwardly seem like enemies but inwardly have deep intentions;
Second, those who directly admonish people to their faces but speak well of them behind their backs;
Third, those who worry and help resolve problems for the sick, the weak, and those in official matters;
Fourth, when seeing people who are poor and lowly, do not abandon them, but think of seeking ways to enrich them.
There are also four types of bad friends:
First, those who are difficult to admonish and understand, who do good deeds out of ignorance, and who associate with the wicked;
Second, those who are taught not to befriend those who enjoy drinking, yet still associate with those who indulge in alcohol;
Third, those who are taught to be self-reliant, yet take on more affairs;
Fourth, those who are taught to befriend the virtuous, yet become close with gamblers.
There are also four types of good friends:
First, seeing people who are poor and destitute, helping them to make a living;
Second, not quarreling or competing with others;
Third, visiting them daily to inquire about their well-being;
Fourth, sitting and standing together, thinking of each other.
There are also four types of good friends:
First, when someone is arrested by officials, hiding them in their home and later resolving the matter;
Second, when someone is sick and weak, taking them in and nursing them;
Third, when a friend dies, to see them off in the coffin;
Fourth, when a friend dies, to think of their family again.
Good friends also have four types:
First, to stop them when they want to fight;
Second, to admonish and stop them when they want to follow bad friends;
Third, to encourage them to engage in livelihood when they do not want to;
Fourth, to teach them to have faith and joy in the scriptures and path when they do not like them.
Bad friends also have four types:
First, to be greatly angry for a small offense;
Second, to be unwilling to do errands when asked during an emergency;
Third, to avoid people and run away when seeing someone in an emergency;
Fourth, to abandon and not look when seeing someone dead.
The Buddha said:
Choose the good ones and follow them, and stay away from the bad ones.
I followed good friends and attained Buddhahood myself.
The Buddha said:
Those who bow in the east refer to children serving their parents, who should do five things:
First, one should think of managing the livelihood;
Second, one should rise early and instruct servants to cook meals on time;
Third, one should not add to the worries of parents;
Fourth, one should think of the kindness of parents;
Fifth, when parents are sick, one should be afraid and seek a doctor to treat them.
Parents also have five things to consider when looking at their child:
First, they should think of making them leave evil and pursue goodness;
Second, they should teach them to calculate and write;
Third, they should teach them to uphold sutras and precepts;
Fourth, they should marry them off early;
Fifth, they should provide them with all that is in the household.
Those who bow with their heads to the south refer to disciples serving their teachers, who should have five things:
First, they should respect and revere them;
Second, they should think of their kindness;
Third, they should follow their teachings;
Fourth, they should think of them without weariness;
Fifth, they should praise them after them.
Teachers also have five things when teaching disciples:
First, they should make them know quickly;
Second, to make one's disciples surpass the disciples of others;
Third, to make them know and not forget;
Fourth, to explain and resolve all doubts and difficulties;
Fifth, to make one's disciples' wisdom surpass that of the teacher.
Prostrating with the head to the west means a wife serving her husband has five duties:
First, when the husband returns from outside, she should rise to greet him;
Second, when the husband is out, she should cook, clean, and wait for him;
Third, she should not have lustful thoughts about other men, and should not scold back or show anger when scolded;
Fourth, she should follow her husband's teachings and admonitions, and should not hide any belongings;
Fifth, she may only lie down after her husband has rested and gone to sleep.
A husband also has five duties in treating his wife:
First, he should respect his wife when coming and going;
Second, he should provide her with food and clothing in a timely manner;
Third, he should give her gold, silver, and jewels;
Fourth, he should entrust all the belongings in the household to her;
Fifth, one should not engage in sexual misconduct with others' spouses.
Bowing to the north means when a person views relatives and friends, there should be five things:
First, seeing them commit evil, privately go to a secluded place, admonish and stop them;
Second, if there is a slight emergency, one should rush to rescue and protect them;
Third, if there is private speech, one should not speak it to others;
Fourth, one should respect and revere each other;
Fifth, one should share one's good things with them, to a greater or lesser extent.
Bowing to the ground means when a high-ranking official views slaves, guests, maids, and servants, there are also five things:
First, one should give them food, clothing, and bedding in a timely manner;
Second, if they are sick and weak, one should call a doctor to treat them;
Third, one should not beat them wantonly;
Fourth, one should not take their private property;
Fifth, when distributing things, one should make it equal.
Slaves, guests, maids, and servants serving a high-ranking official also have five things:
First, one should rise early, not waiting for the master to call;
Second, one should be mindful in doing what needs to be done;
Third, one should cherish the master's belongings and not discard them to beggars;
Fourth, when the master comes and goes, one should see him off and welcome him back;
Fifth, one should praise the master's virtues and not speak of his faults.

The Buddha spoke a verse:
When the rooster crows, rise early, put on your robe and come down from the bed,
Wash and rinse to purify your mind, with both hands offer flowers and incense.
The Buddha is revered, surpassing all gods, demons and spirits cannot compare,
Bow your head and circumambulate the pagoda and temple, join your palms and pay homage to the ten directions.
The wise who are not diligent are like a tree without roots,
With the roots cut off, the branches and leaves fall - when will they ever be connected again?
Picking flowers and placing them in the sun, how long can they remain fresh?
Letting the mind run wild and unrestrained, what can be said when life is over?
People should contemplate impermanence, there is no fixed time for death to come,
Offending and not being aware of it, when life is over, one deceives oneself.
Now entering hell, when will there be a time of release?
The wise accept the Buddha's words, uphold the precepts and be cautious, do not doubt.
The Buddha is like a beautiful flower tree, there is no one who does not love and enjoy it,
People everywhere hear this, and all rejoice.
When I attain Buddhahood, I vow to be like the Dharma King,
Delivering all from birth and death, there will be none who are not liberated.
The virtue of precepts can be relied upon, blessings and rewards always follow oneself,
In the present life, one becomes a great person, and in the end, one is far from the three evil paths.
Being cautious eliminates fear and dread. Merit and virtue are revered in the three realms.
Ghosts, spirits, and evil poisons do not harm those who keep the precepts.
Falling into worldly life and suffering, life is as fleeting as a flash of lightning.
When old age, sickness, and death arrive, there is no power to resist them.
There are no relatives to rely on, no place to hide.
Even heavenly blessings have an end, how much less can human life last long?
Parents, family, and residence are like guests staying temporarily.
The lifespan of past lives is exhausted, and one abandons the old to receive the new.
Each one is pursued by their own actions, without end like a wheel.
Arising and ceasing follow from good and evil, with birth and death as the twelve links of dependent origination.
In the present body, wandering and avoiding chaos, one benefits and nurtures all people.
Compassionately pitying those who fall into various delusions, they are submerged in the deep abyss.
Exerting oneself in the six perfections, practicing to attain spontaneity,
Therefore I bow my head in reverence, taking refuge in the Heaven of Heavens.
The human body is difficult to obtain, and having obtained it, one indulges in desires,
Greedy for sex in the conscious mind, feeling and thought are never satisfied.
Preemptively planting the seedlings of the next life, joyfully going to hell,
The six sense faculties are fortunate to be complete, why do you trouble and humiliate yourself?
All are able to rectify the mind, the auspiciousness of the spirits of the three worlds,
Not greedy for the eight difficulties, following practice and being born in the ten directions.
The place of birth is diligent, the six perfections are the bridge,
Extensively encouraging infinite wisdom, all are illuminated by the spiritual light.
